articles.headline: Toll of Deadly Tornadoes in South Climbs Past 50
articles.snippet: Authorities were searching for victims after a wide swath of storms packing tornadoes and hail swept the South.
articles.abstract: Authorities were searching for victims after a wide swath of storms packing tornadoes and hail swept the South.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATKINS, Ark.  Residents in five Southern states rose Wednesday to widespread clusters of destruction caused by an unusually ferocious winter tornado system. At least 55 people were killed, and scores more were injured.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Brenda Goodman

articles.headline: Pet Food Indictments for 3 Firms
articles.snippet: Two Chinese companies and an American importer were indicted  on charges of intentionally defrauding American manufacturers about poisonous ingredients used in pet food.
articles.abstract: Two Chinese companies and an American importer were indicted  on charges of intentionally defrauding American manufacturers about poisonous ingredients used in pet food.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two Chinese companies and an American importer were indicted Wednesday on charges of intentionally defrauding and misleading American manufacturers about poisonous ingredients used in pet food last year.

articles.headline: Northwest and Delta Talk Merger
articles.snippet: The combination could force other carriers to seek partners, people with knowledge of the talks said Wednesday.
articles.abstract: The combination could force other carriers to seek partners, people with knowledge of the talks said Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: In events that could reshape the airline industry, merger talks have picked up pace between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines, a combination that could force other carriers to seek partners, people with knowledge of the talks said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jeff Bailey

articles.headline: Obama Made Some Inroads, but Fervor Fell Short at End
articles.snippet: Tuesday’s results did not live up to the promise signaled by Barack Obama’s dramatic march of rallies leading up to the vote.
articles.abstract: Tuesday’s results did not live up to the promise signaled by Barack Obama’s dramatic march of rallies leading up to the vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois made some headway in building a coalition of support among Democrats in Tuesday’s cross-country sprint of primaries.

articles.headline: An Industry Imperiled by Falling Profits and Shrinking Ads
articles.snippet: Some say 2008 will mark a dark turning point for the newspaper industry, which has been besieged by shrinking profits and tumbling stock prices.
articles.abstract: Some say 2008 will mark a dark turning point for the newspaper industry, which has been besieged by shrinking profits and tumbling stock prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: In just the last few weeks, The San Diego Union-Tribune eliminated more than 100 jobs, one-tenth of its work force. The Chicago Sun-Times began a major round of newsroom layoffs, then put itself up for sale, and publishers in Minneapolis and Philadelphia warned that tough economics could force cuts there.

articles.headline: Slide Show Mounted in a Frame
articles.snippet: A new line of digital picture frames features lower prices, more pixels and the inevitable glitches.
articles.abstract: A new line of digital picture frames features lower prices, more pixels and the inevitable glitches.
articles.lead_paragraph: The other day at a trade show, a reader accosted me. “I can’t believe you gave speech-recognition software a good review,” he scolded. “I had an awful experience with it! I wound up sticking it in a drawer.”

articles.headline: Craving the High That Risky Trading Can Bring
articles.snippet: It is easy to dismiss Jérôme Kerviel, the rogue trader at Société Générale, as a fluke. So here is a sobering thought for Wall Street: There may be a bit of Mr. Kerviel in all of us.
articles.abstract: It is easy to dismiss Jérôme Kerviel, the rogue trader at Société Générale, as a fluke. So here is a sobering thought for Wall Street: There may be a bit of Mr. Kerviel in all of us.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is easy to dismiss Jérôme Kerviel, the rogue trader at Société Générale, as a fluke.

articles.headline: Obama and Clinton Brace for a Long-Distance Run
articles.snippet: The Democrats are preparing for a lengthy nomination fight, while John McCain is hoping to seal up the Republican nomination quickly.
articles.abstract: The Democrats are preparing for a lengthy nomination fight, while John McCain is hoping to seal up the Republican nomination quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: With no breakout winner in Tuesday’s Democratic primaries, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama on Wednesday began fortifying for a drawn-out nomination fight, with Mrs. Clinton disclosing that she had lent her campaign $5 million while Mr. Obama raised $3 million online in a single day and rejected calls for more debates.

articles.headline: Fighting in Chad’s Capital Ebbs, but Problems Loom
articles.snippet: The clash that nearly toppled the government of Chad has heightened tensions with its neighbor Sudan.
articles.abstract: The clash that nearly toppled the government of Chad has heightened tensions with its neighbor Sudan.
articles.lead_paragraph: NDJAMENA, Chad  The body brigade had its work cut out for it.

articles.headline: Drug Ads Raise Questions for Heart Pioneer
articles.snippet: Dr. Robert Jarvik’s appearance in television ads for Lipitor has helped rekindle a smoldering debate.
articles.abstract: Dr. Robert Jarvik’s appearance in television ads for Lipitor has helped rekindle a smoldering debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert Jarvik is best known for the artificial heart he pioneered more than a quarter-century ago. Since then he had toiled in relative obscurity  until he began appearing in television ads two years ago for the Pfizer cholesterol drug Lipitor.
